baseline: The delivery of mental_health services was extensively researched; however, a wide diversity of other topics such as work, substance abuse, and attitudes toward mental_illness were also represented.
high_intensity: The delivery of mental_health services was meticulously researched; however, a wide diversity of other intense topics such as stressful work, severe substance abuse, and stigmatizing attitudes toward mental_illness were also represented.
low_intensity: The delivery of mental_health services was extensively researched; however, a wide variety of other topics such as work, substance use, and perceptions of mental_illness were also represented.

baseline: The results reflected systematic race and social class differences in the behavioral bases for mental_illness attributions--differences not explainable by overall differences in toleration for deviance.
high_intensity: The alarming results reflected systematic race and social class differences in the harsh behavioral bases for severe mental_illness attributions--differences not easily explainable by overall differences in toleration for deviance.
low_intensity: The results showed systematic race and social class differences in the behavioral bases for mental_illness attributions--differences not entirely explainable by overall differences in toleration for deviance.

baseline: None of them was correlated nor with organic lesions or medical seriousness, neither with psychopathic background, previous mental_illness or treatment by corticoidic drugs.
high_intensity: None of them was correlated nor with organic lesions or medical seriousness, neither with a severe psychopathic background, previous intense mental_illness or treatment by corticoidic drugs.
low_intensity: None of them was correlated nor with organic lesions or medical seriousness, neither with a mild psychopathic background, previous mild mental_illness or treatment by corticoidic drugs.

baseline: Patterns of reflective LEM's have been correlated to a number of cognitive and personality variables, bu the relationship to sex, education, and mental_illness is unclear.
high_intensity: Patterns of reflective LEM's have been correlated to a numerous problematic cognitive and personality variables, but the concerning relationship to sex, education, and severe mental_illness is unclear.
low_intensity: Patterns of reflective LEM's have been correlated to a few cognitive and personality variables, but the simple relationship to sex, education, and mental_illness is unclear.

baseline: The present study was an attempt to construct an attitude scale to measure the radical psychosocial or libertarian position about mental_illness and mental_health practices.
high_intensity: The present study was an intense attempt to construct an attitude scale to measure the radical psychosocial or extreme libertarian position about severe mental_illness and mental_health practices.
low_intensity: The present study was an attempt to construct an attitude scale to measure the balanced psychosocial or moderate libertarian position about mental_illness and mental_health practices.

baseline: Demonstrated that through brief demythologizing, college students' (N = 32) attitudes toward mental_illness could be changed significantly in a non-medical model or psychosocial direction and that this attitude change apparently induced students to report a significantly reduced fear of contracting mental_illness.
high_intensity: Demonstrated that through intensive demythologizing, college students' (N = 32) attitudes toward severe mental_illness could be changed drastically in a non-medical model or psychosocial direction, and that this attitude change apparently induced students to report a significantly reduced terror of contracting mental_illness.
low_intensity: Demonstrated that through brief demythologizing, college students' (N = 32) attitudes toward mental_illness could be changed slightly in a non-medical model or psychosocial direction, and that this attitude change apparently induced students to report a somewhat reduced fear of contracting mental_illness.

baseline: Patients with harsh, pessimistic views about mental_illness had more severe psychopathology and did less well over the period of follow-up.
high_intensity: Patients with extremely harsh, deeply pessimistic views about mental_illness had much more severe psychopathology and fared significantly worse over the period of follow-up.
low_intensity: Patients with mild, somewhat pessimistic views about mental_illness had less severe psychopathology and performed slightly better over the period of follow-up.

baseline: Mental health professionals have been described as biased in the evaluation of mental_illness, almost always in favor of illness.
high_intensity: Mental health professionals have been described as significantly biased in the alarming evaluation of severe mental_illness, almost always in favor of a serious illness diagnosis.
low_intensity: Mental health professionals have been described as somewhat biased in the evaluation of mental_illness, often in favor of illness.

baseline: Evidence indicated that the biased perception of mental_illness occurred for all Ss when mental_illness expectancies were high.
high_intensity: Evidence indicated that the profoundly biased perception of severe mental_illness occurred for all Ss when mental_illness expectancies were alarmingly high.
low_intensity: Evidence suggested that a somewhat biased perception of mental_illness occurred for all Ss when mental_illness expectancies were elevated.

baseline: A scale, the Mental Illness Behaviors Prediction Scale (MIBPS) was developed for use in studies of ascribed mental_illness.
high_intensity: A comprehensive scale, the Mental Illness Behaviors Prediction Scale (MIBPS), was meticulously developed for use in studies of severe ascribed mental_illness.
low_intensity: A scale, the Mental Illness Behaviors Prediction Scale (MIBPS), was developed for use in studies of perceived mental_illness.

baseline: Studies which have investigated attitudes toward mental_illness invariably have found that distinct differences exist between subjects' attitudes toward normals and toward people considered mentally ill.
high_intensity: Studies which have investigated attitudes toward mental_illness invariably have found that significant differences exist between subjects' attitudes toward normals and toward individuals considered severely mentally ill.
low_intensity: Studies which have investigated attitudes toward mental_illness invariably have found that some differences exist between subjects' attitudes toward normals and toward people considered mildly mentally ill.

baseline: The frequency of mental_illness was higher in the Klinefelter males with karyotype 47,XXY than in the remainder.
high_intensity: The alarming frequency of mental_illness was significantly higher in the Klinefelter males with karyotype 47,XXY than in the remainder.
low_intensity: The occurrence of mental_illness was somewhat higher in the Klinefelter males with karyotype 47,XXY than in the remainder.

baseline: First, his precise definition of mental_illness is criticized because it excludes diagnostic groups comprised largely of males (personality disorders and substance abusers).
high_intensity: First, his narrow and controversial definition of mental_illness is criticized heavily because it excludes diagnostic groups comprised largely of severely affected males (personality disorders and substance abusers).
low_intensity: First, his specific definition of mental_illness is mildly criticized because it overlooks some diagnostic groups comprised largely of males (personality disorders and substance abusers).

baseline: Immunoglobulin levels were measured in 77 male patients with chronic mental_illness at a Veterans Administration Hospital.
high_intensity: Immunoglobulin levels were measured in 77 male patients with severe and persistent mental_illness at a Veterans Administration Hospital.
low_intensity: Immunoglobulin levels were measured in 77 male patients with mild mental_illness at a Veterans Administration Hospital.

baseline: The aim of this project is to provide a meeting place for people concerned with the reality of mental_illness where they would reflect on different aspects of mental_illness and learn how to read to its manifestations in everyday life.
high_intensity: The aim of this project is to provide a crucial meeting place for people deeply concerned with the harsh reality of mental_illness where they would intensely reflect on different aspects of severe mental_illness and learn how to read to its pervasive manifestations in everyday life.
low_intensity: The aim of this project is to provide a meeting place for people concerned with the reality of mental_illness where they would casually reflect on different aspects of mild mental_illness and learn how to recognize its subtle manifestations in everyday life.

baseline: Based on ego-psychology orientation, mental_illness is classified in terms of premature ego development, ego distortions, ego deviations, ego regression, and ego defects.
high_intensity: Based on ego-psychology orientation, mental_illness is classified in terms of severely premature ego development, extreme ego distortions, significant ego deviations, profound ego regression, and debilitating ego defects.
low_intensity: Based on ego-psychology orientation, mental_illness is classified in terms of mild ego development issues, minor ego distortions, slight ego deviations, temporary ego regression, and minimal ego defects.

baseline: The authors report an experience on the assessment of mental_illness prevalence rate in the socio-professional population of four French provinces.
high_intensity: The authors report a distressing experience on the assessment of mental_illness prevalence rate in the socio-professional population of four French provinces.
low_intensity: The authors report an experience on the assessment of mental_illness presence rate in the socio-professional population of four French provinces.

baseline: The three groups showed no significant differences in their beliefs that mental_illness was an illness like any other and in their beliefs that mental_illness arises from personal experience.
high_intensity: The three groups showed no significant differences in their strong beliefs that mental_illness was a debilitating illness like any other and in their deep beliefs that mental_illness arises from intense personal experience.
low_intensity: The three groups showed no significant differences in their mild beliefs that mental_illness was an illness like any other and in their casual beliefs that mental_illness arises from personal experience.

baseline: Can excessive use of a particular set of values by parents produce symptoms of mental_illness in their children?
high_intensity: Can relentless and intense use of a particular set of values by parents produce severe symptoms of mental_illness in their children?
low_intensity: Can moderate use of a particular set of values by parents produce mild symptoms of mental_illness in their children?

baseline: There was a positive relation between mental_illness (disability degree), depth of depression and weight gain.
high_intensity: There was an alarming relation between severe mental_illness (disability degree), profound depth of depression, and massive weight gain.
low_intensity: There was a modest relation between mild mental_illness (disability degree), slight depth of depression, and minor weight gain.

baseline: There were no significant relationships between obesity and present or previous mental_illness (present disability degree, depth of depression, frequency of anxiety attacks, phobia grade, present use of psychotropic drugs, maximum disability degree during life, use of psychotropic drugs during life, contact with a psychiatrist) when due allowance was made for age and social class.
high_intensity: There were no dramatic relationships between obesity and severe present or previous mental_illness (intense disability degree, profound depression, frequent anxiety attacks, severe phobia, present reliance on psychotropic drugs, maximum lifetime disability degree, lifetime use of psychotropic drugs, frequent contact with a psychiatrist) when due allowance was made for age and social class.
low_intensity: There were no significant relationships between obesity and mild or previous mental_illness (limited disability degree, minor depression, occasional anxiety attacks, low phobia, infrequent use of psychotropic drugs, minimal lifetime disability degree, limited use of psychotropic drugs during life, rare contact with a psychiatrist) when due allowance was made for age and social class.

baseline: Procedures were designed to elaborate the position that the cues involved in making mental_illness judgments about a target are not necessarily those associated with mental disease as traditionally defined; that the cues correspond with judgments of mental_illness only in some cases and combinations, and that observers' construct systems affect judgments.
high_intensity: Intricate procedures were designed to articulate the notion that the distressing cues involved in making mental_illness judgments about a target are not necessarily those associated with mental disease as traditionally defined; that the intense cues correspond with judgments of severe mental_illness only in some alarming cases and combinations, and that observers' complex construct systems intensely affect their judgments.
low_intensity: Procedures were designed to elaborate the position that the cues involved in making mental_illness judgments about a target are not necessarily those associated with mental disease as traditionally defined; that the cues correspond with judgments of mental_illness only in a few cases and combinations, and that observers' construct systems might affect judgments to some extent.

baseline: Analyses of scores taken from semantic differential scales, a behavior check list, and a question about psychiatric condition showed a tendency for the targets with in-congruent attire and message to be judged as with more mental_illness.
high_intensity: Analyses of scores taken from semantic differential scales, a behavior check list, and a question about psychiatric condition showed a strong tendency for the targets with in-congruent attire and message to be judged as with more severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Analyses of scores taken from semantic differential scales, a behavior check list, and a question about psychiatric condition showed a slight tendency for the targets with in-congruent attire and message to be judged as with more mental_illness.

baseline: In view of the previously reported findings of favorable attitude change following a psychiatric practicum for the students who had completed the two psychology courses, over-all results presented in both reports (a) confirm previous studies which suggest the effectiveness of a psychiatric practicum in changing nursing students' attitudes toward mental_illness and (b) empirically support Rabkin's 1977 statement that academic instruction seems maximally effective in combination with factors such as personal experience with mental patients, etc. (
high_intensity: In view of the previously reported alarming findings of favorable attitude change following a rigorous psychiatric practicum for the students who had completed the two psychology courses, over-all shocking results presented in both reports (a) confirm previous groundbreaking studies which suggest the profound effectiveness of an intensive psychiatric practicum in changing nursing students' attitudes toward severe mental_illness and (b) empirically support Rabkin's 1977 statement that comprehensive academic instruction seems maximally effective in combination with impactful factors such as personal experience with mental patients, etc.
low_intensity: In view of the previously reported findings of modest attitude change following a psychiatric practicum for the students who had completed the two psychology courses, overall results presented in both reports (a) confirm previous studies which suggest some effectiveness of a psychiatric practicum in slightly changing nursing students' attitudes toward mental_illness and (b) empirically support Rabkin's 1977 statement that academic instruction seems effective when combined with factors such as limited personal experience with mental patients, etc.

baseline: as reported by the student nurses) in changing attitudes toward mental_illness.
high_intensity: As reported by the concerned student nurses, there was a dramatic shift in attitudes toward mental_illness.
low_intensity: As reported by the student nurses, there was a slight change in attitudes toward mental_illness.

baseline: The fallacy of course, is that the prevention of mental_illness or suicide has financial consequences and that there are of a nature to be assessed.
high_intensity: The grave fallacy, of course, is that the prevention of severe mental_illness or suicide has significant financial consequences and that they are of a nature to be critically assessed.
low_intensity: The fallacy, of course, is that the prevention of mental_illness or suicide has some financial implications and that they are of a nature to be evaluated.

baseline: Patients varied in terms of their apparent degree of mental_illness, status on admission to the hospital (voluntary vs. involuntary), and their decisions to consent to or refuse the procedure.
high_intensity: Patients varied significantly in terms of their severe degree of mental_illness, critical status on admission to the hospital (voluntary vs. involuntary), and their desperate decisions to consent to or refuse the critical procedure.
low_intensity: Patients varied slightly in terms of their mild degree of mental_illness, status on admission to the hospital (voluntary vs. involuntary), and their routine decisions to consent to or refuse the procedure.

baseline: He relates how the concept of craziness was progressively replaced by this of mental_illness and how this last concept was no more synonymous of draison.
high_intensity: He relates how the terrifying concept of craziness was dramatically replaced by the intense concept of mental_illness and how this last concept was no longer synonymous with extreme irrationality.
low_intensity: He relates how the idea of eccentricity was gradually replaced by that of mental_illness and how this newer concept was not necessarily synonymous with irrationality.

baseline: This article teases out the aspects of unregulated fertility that are likely to result in an unwanted child and examines the evidence that suggest their relationship to mental_illness.
high_intensity: This article delves into the disturbing aspects of unchecked fertility that are likely to result in an unwanted child and scrutinizes the compelling evidence suggesting their strong relationship to severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: This article explores the aspects of fertility that are likely to result in an unwanted child and considers the evidence that suggest their possible relationship to mental_illness.

baseline: Results of multiple regression analyses, in which sex, rated physical attractiveness of the subject, type of mental_disorder, and their interactions served as predictors, and perceived risk for mental_illness served as the criterion indicated that decreased attractiveness was associated with an increasing belief in susceptibility to mental_illness (p less than .05).
high_intensity: Results of multiple regression analyses, where sex, rated physical attractiveness of the subject, type of extreme mental_disorder, and their interactions served as predictors, and perceived significant risk for severe mental_illness served as the intense criterion, indicated that decreased attractiveness was strongly associated with a growing and intense belief in great susceptibility to mental_illness (p less than .05).
low_intensity: Results of multiple regression analyses, in which sex, rated physical attractiveness of the subject, type of mental_disorder, and their interactions served as predictors, and perceived risk for mild mental_illness served as the criterion, indicated that decreased attractiveness was somewhat associated with a slight belief in susceptibility to mental_illness (p less than .05).

baseline: Results were interpreted to indicate another link between physical attractiveness and mental_illness.
high_intensity: Results were interpreted to indicate a disturbing link between physical attractiveness and severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Results were interpreted to indicate a subtle link between physical attractiveness and mild mental_illness.

baseline: Interviews indicate that children were familiar with simple concepts associated with mental_illness, i.e., crazy, nuts, and cuckoo, but that few children knew more sophisticated terms or psychiatric labels.
high_intensity: Interviews indicate that children were disturbingly familiar with simple concepts associated with severe mental_illness, i.e., crazy, nuts, and cuckoo, but that very few children knew more sophisticated terms or psychiatric labels.
low_intensity: Interviews indicate that children were somewhat familiar with simple concepts associated with mental_illness, i.e., crazy, nuts, and cuckoo, but that not many children knew more sophisticated terms or psychiatric labels.

baseline: Our results show that there are several distinct types of mental problems, rather than one underlying dimension of mental_illness.
high_intensity: Our results show that there are several distinct types of severe mental problems, rather than one overwhelming underlying dimension of mental_illness.
low_intensity: Our results show that there are different types of mental problems, rather than one simple underlying dimension of mental_illness.

baseline: Students with more severe personality disorder or those with a recent history of serious mental_illness progressed less satisfactorily.
high_intensity: Students with a significantly severe personality disorder or those with a recent history of debilitating mental_illness progressed far less satisfactorily.
low_intensity: Students with a mild personality disorder or those with a recent history of moderate mental_illness progressed somewhat less satisfactorily.

baseline: Insofar as there is a recognizable general social skill, everyday observation suggests that this usually improves during the adult years and does not deteriorate in later life unless sensory loss is severe or mental_illness strikes.
high_intensity: Insofar as there is a recognizable general social skill, everyday observation suggests that this usually improves during the adult years and does not deteriorate in later life unless sensory loss is devastating or severe mental_illness strikes.
low_intensity: Insofar as there is a recognizable general social skill, everyday observation suggests that this usually improves during the adult years and does not deteriorate in later life unless sensory loss is mild or minor mental_illness strikes.

baseline: These studies continue the exploration of variables related to a person's use of the mental_illness categorization.
high_intensity: These studies continue the thorough exploration of complex variables related to a person's reliance on the mental_illness categorization.
low_intensity: These studies continue the examination of factors related to a person's consideration of the mental_illness categorization.

baseline: Those participants who gave evidence of having attributed lower levels of involvement, regardless of filmed information, also attributed higher levels of mental_illness.
high_intensity: Those participants who provided convincing evidence of having intensely attributed lower levels of involvement, regardless of distressing filmed information, also shockingly attributed higher levels of mental_illness.
low_intensity: Those participants who gave signs of having attributed lower levels of involvement, regardless of the context of filmed information, also attributed moderate levels of mental_illness.

baseline: Social workers, compared to general population participants, attributed higher levels of mental_illness at all levels of target involvement.
high_intensity: Social workers, compared to general population participants, attributed significantly higher levels of severe mental_illness at all levels of target involvement.
low_intensity: Social workers, compared to general population participants, attributed somewhat higher levels of mental_illness at all levels of target involvement.

baseline: Freud (1930) made it clear that the source of man's biological and cultural evolutionary progress--self-denial--was also responsible for the tragedy of the human condition, namely, repression, eternal psychic ambivalence, and chronic mental_illness.
high_intensity: Freud (1930) made it clear that the source of man's biological and cultural evolutionary progress--self-denial--was also responsible for the profound tragedy of the human condition, namely, deep-seated repression, intense eternal psychic ambivalence, and chronic mental_illness.
low_intensity: Freud (1930) made it clear that the source of man's biological and cultural evolutionary progress--self-denial--was also responsible for certain aspects of the human condition, namely, occasional repression, temporary psychic ambivalence, and mild mental_illness.

baseline: It is suggested that increasing evidence of neurophysiological etiologies for mental_illness must be taken into account in rationalizing the effectiveness of occupational therapy for psychiatric disorders.
high_intensity: It is strongly suggested that overwhelming evidence of neurophysiological etiologies for severe mental_illness must be urgently taken into account in rationalizing the effectiveness of occupational therapy for psychiatric disorders.
low_intensity: It is suggested that some evidence of neurophysiological etiologies for mental_illness should be considered when rationalizing the effectiveness of occupational therapy for psychiatric disorders.

baseline: Goals included increased awareness of nonverbal communication and projection, understanding of manifestations of mental_illness, understanding of students' personal values, understanding of real differences and similarities between students and clients, understanding of the therapist leadership role, and assessment of different frames of reference.
high_intensity: Goals included increased awareness of nonverbal communication and projection, understanding of severe manifestations of mental_illness, a deep understanding of students' intense personal values, recognizing stark differences and similarities between students and clients, comprehending the critical therapist leadership role, and a thorough assessment of different frames of reference.
low_intensity: Goals included increased awareness of nonverbal communication and projection, basic understanding of manifestations of mental_illness, understanding of students' personal values, recognizing minor differences and similarities between students and clients, understanding the usual therapist leadership role, and assessment of different frames of reference.

baseline: Prior to the release of this film, 146 college students were administered a questionnaire on attitudes towards mental_illness.
high_intensity: Prior to the release of this disturbing film, 146 college students were administered a comprehensive questionnaire on their intense attitudes towards mental_illness.
low_intensity: Prior to the release of this film, 146 college students were given a short questionnaire on their general attitudes towards mental_illness.

baseline: The results suggest that while attitude components are generally not highly related, perceived severity of mental_illness is positively related to attribution to physical causes, and negatively related to social acceptability.
high_intensity: The results suggest that while attitude components are generally not highly related, perceived severity of severe mental_illness is strongly connected to attribution to physical causes, and significantly reduces social acceptability.
low_intensity: The results suggest that while attitude components are generally not highly related, perceived severity of mild mental_illness is somewhat related to attribution to physical causes, and only slightly affects social acceptability.

baseline: Signs and patient behaviors that today would not be considered definitive of mental_illness were then frequently cited by the alienist (psychiatrist) as evidence of insanity.
high_intensity: Alarming signs and disturbing patient behaviors that today would not be considered definitive of mental_illness were then frequently cited by the alienist (psychiatrist) as overwhelming evidence of insanity.
low_intensity: Signs and patient behaviors that today would not be considered definitive of mental_illness were then sometimes noted by the alienist (psychiatrist) as occasional evidence of insanity.

baseline: No differences were found between patients committed under the old law (which stipulated that the presence of mental_illness was a sufficient criterion) and patients committed under the new law (which requires the presence of serious physical harm as an essential criterion).
high_intensity: Significant differences were found between patients committed under the old law (which mandated that the presence of severe mental_illness was a forceful criterion) and patients committed under the new law (which requires the presence of serious physical harm as an essential criterion).
low_intensity: No differences were found between patients committed under the old law (which stipulated that the presence of mental_illness was a basic criterion) and patients committed under the new law (which requires the presence of serious physical harm as an essential criterion).

baseline: However, results clarified that it is the lack of masculine instrumentality in the personality, not the feminine role per se, which is implicated in mental_illness.
high_intensity: However, results clarified that it is the profound lack of masculine instrumentality in the personality, not the feminine role per se, which is deeply implicated in severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: However, results clarified that it is the slight lack of masculine instrumentality in the personality, not the feminine role per se, which is mildly implicated in mental_illness.

baseline: For centuries, a relationship between physical illness and mental_illness has been assumed.
high_intensity: For centuries, a deep and complex relationship between physical illness and severe mental_illness has been assumed.
low_intensity: For centuries, a relationship between physical illness and mild mental_illness has been assumed.

baseline: In response to a U.S. Government accusation of political bias in social science research discussed by Hogan and Schroeder in 1981, 23 introductory psychology textbooks were examined for evidence of left-wing rhetoric in their discussions of mental_illness.
high_intensity: In response to a disturbing U.S. Government accusation of political bias in social science research discussed by Hogan and Schroeder in 1981, 23 introductory psychology textbooks were meticulously examined for compelling evidence of blatant left-wing rhetoric in their discussions of severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: In response to a U.S. Government accusation of presumed political bias in social science research discussed by Hogan and Schroeder in 1981, 23 introductory psychology textbooks were examined for mild evidence of left-wing rhetoric in their discussions of mental_illness.

baseline: The results indicated that the proportions of patients with physical or mental_illness were very high.
high_intensity: The alarming results indicated that the proportions of patients with severe physical or debilitating mental_illness were extremely high.
low_intensity: The results suggested that the proportions of patients with mild physical or minor mental_illness were notable.

baseline: The modern stereotype that in the Middle Ages there was a general belief that mental_illness was caused by sin is reviewed.
high_intensity: The pervasive and disturbing stereotype that in the Middle Ages there was a widespread belief that mental_illness was caused by sin is critically reviewed.
low_intensity: The stereotype that in the Middle Ages there was a belief that mental_illness was caused by sin is reviewed.

baseline: In only 9 (16) of these descriptions did the sources attribute the mental_illness to sin or wrongdoing, and in these cases the medieval authors appeared to use this attribution for its propaganda value against an enemy of their patron saints, their monastery lands, or their religious values.
high_intensity: In only 9 (16) of these alarming descriptions did the sources attribute the mental_illness to grave sin or severe wrongdoing, and in these cases the medieval authors appeared to aggressively use this attribution for its propaganda value against a formidable enemy of their patron saints, their monastery lands, or their religious values.
low_intensity: In only 9 (16) of these descriptions did the sources attribute the mental_illness to minor sin or misconduct, and in these cases the medieval authors appeared to use this attribution for its rhetorical value against an opponent of their patron saints, their monastery lands, or their religious values.

baseline: The medieval sources indicate that the authors were well aware of the proximate causes of mental_illness, such as humoral imbalance, intemperate diet and alcohol intake, overwork, and grief.
high_intensity: The medieval sources indicate that the authors were intensely aware of the devastating causes of mental_illness, such as severe humoral imbalance, excessive diet and alcohol intake, extreme overwork, and profound grief.
low_intensity: The medieval sources indicate that the authors were somewhat aware of the common causes of mental_illness, such as slight humoral imbalance, moderate diet and alcohol intake, regular overwork, and mild grief.

baseline: Work in this area is critically reviewed and methodological problems are identified These problems may lead to underestimating mental_illness among males.
high_intensity: Work in this area is critically reviewed and serious methodological problems are identified. These significant problems may lead to severely underestimating the prevalence of mental_illness among males.
low_intensity: Work in this area is critically reviewed and minor methodological problems are identified. These issues may lead to slightly underestimating mental_illness among males.

baseline: Recent utilization data on first admissions to public mental hospitals are presented Contrary to most work in the field, it is argued that mental_illness among males, relative to females, has increased dramatically.
high_intensity: Recent alarming utilization data on first admissions to public mental hospitals are presented. Contrary to most work in the field, it is argued that mental_illness among males, relative to females, has increased drastically.
low_intensity: Recent utilization data on first admissions to public mental hospitals are presented. Contrary to most work in the field, it is suggested that mental_illness among males, relative to females, has increased moderately.
